metadata.titleEn: Daily precipitation data with 10km resolution in the upper Brahmaputra (Yarlung Zangbo River) Basin (1961-2016)
metadata.description: Daily precipitation data was reconstructed for streamflow simulation in the entire UB by combining orographic and linear correction approaches based on 262 gauge observations. The reconstructed precipitation is used to drive the VIC hydrological model linked with a temperature-index model (VIC-Glacier) , and is inversely evaluated by comparing with observed discharge, glacier area changes, and MODIS-based snow cover faction (SCF) data in the upper Brahmaputra Basin.
metadata.instructions: The data contains 3390 grid files. Each file has four columns, namely year, month, day and precipitation. The file is named data_ Latitude_ Longitude.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method that integrates elevation terrain correction and linear correction techniques to enhance precipitation data accuracy in a large river basin?
Example.Answer: An example of a data collection method that integrates elevation terrain correction and linear correction techniques can be seen in the reconstruction of daily precipitation data from 1961 to 2016 at a 10km resolution for the Yarlung Zangbo River Basin. This method utilized existing monthly precipitation data from 262 rain gauges collected from 2014 to 2016. The approach combined elevation terrain and linear corrections to adjust precipitation data from the China Meteorological Administration (CMA) and Global Land Data Assimilation Systems (GLDAS), enhancing the accuracy and reliability of the dataset.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the characteristics and methodologies of data collection used to create a high-resolution precipitation dataset in the Yarlung Zangbo River Basin between 1961 and 2016?
Feature Specification.Answer: 10 km resolution, daily precipitation data, 1961 to 2016, Yarlung Zangbo River Basin, elevation terrain correction, linear correction methods, 262 rain gauges, VIC hydrological model, validated using measured runoff, MODIS, glacier inventory data

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors have led to the need for recalibrating precipitation data using elevation and linear corrections in the Yarlung Zangbo River Basin?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The recalibration of precipitation data using elevation and linear corrections was necessary to enhance the accuracy of the data derived from the China Meteorological Administration (CMA) and Global Land Data Assimilation Systems (GLDAS). This was particularly important due to the complex topography of the Yarlung Zangbo River Basin, which affects precipitation distribution. By integrating data from 262 existing rain gauges and employing these corrections, researchers aimed to reconstruct daily precipitation data with a 10km resolution from 1961 to 2016, ensuring it accurately reflects the unique climatic and geographic conditions of the basin and its sub-basins.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the primary objectives behind reconstructing a dataset with 10km resolution daily precipitation data for the Yarlung Zangbo River Basin and its sub-basins from 1961 to 2016?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goal is to create a high-resolution and accurate dataset of daily precipitation for the Yarlung Zangbo River Basin by correcting existing data from the China Meteorological Administration and Global Land Data Assimilation Systems using elevation and linear correction methods. This reconstructed dataset is intended to drive the VIC hydrological model for simulating runoff and ice-snow areas across the basin and its sub-basins, facilitating validation with observed runoff, MODIS data, and glacier inventory data.
